core_idea: The document outlines Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates employers to provide earned paid sick leave to employees, including specific provisions for accrual, usage, and protections during public health emergencies such as COVID-19. It details employee eligibility, reasons for leave, employer obligations, enforcement mechanisms, and anti-retaliation protections to ensure workers can take necessary sick leave without penalty. The act aims to promote workplace health and safety by guaranteeing paid sick leave access and compliance standards for employers statewide.
initial_content:
Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.
Employee Eligibility
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.
How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.
Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:
The employee:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee needs to care for a family member who:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:
(i) The employee’s place of business; or
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.
Taking Paid Sick Leave
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.
Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.
Paid Sick Leave at Separation
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.
Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):
An employee’s need to:
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(v) Care for a family member who:
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
Or if:
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
Or to:
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;
Or due to:
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.
Recordkeeping
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.
Anti-Retaliation
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.
Notice to Employees
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.
Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.
***
Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, or any other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.

optimizations.query: new employment laws in colorado 2023 for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado enacted several new employment laws affecting small businesses, with key changes in equal pay, paid sick leave, discrimination standards, and employee protections:

1. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (SB 23-105, effective January 1, 2024):**  
   - Employers must post job opportunities internally and externally with specific salary ranges, benefits descriptions, and application deadlines, excluding routine career development or progression changes.  
   - Employers with no physical presence in Colorado and fewer than 15 remote employees in the state have a limited notice requirement until July 1, 2029.  
   - Post-hire, employers must notify employees about the selected candidate’s name, former and new job titles (if internal hire), and how to express interest in similar jobs.  
   - The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) gains enhanced enforcement powers, including complaint investigation and mediation for wage discrimination claims, with back pay recoverable up to six years.  
   These changes aim to increase pay transparency and reduce wage discrimination [1][2][3].

2. **Expanded Paid Sick Leave Uses (SB 23-017, effective August 7, 2023):**  
   - Under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), employees may now use accrued paid sick leave to grieve or attend funerals for family members, care for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events, and evacuate their residence under similar conditions.  
   - Employers must update sick leave policies accordingly and cannot retaliate against employees for taking such leave [1][2][3][6].

3. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights Act (POWR) (SB 23-172, effective August 7, 2023):**  
   - Revises workplace harassment standards, making it easier for employees to bring claims by lowering the burden of proof and expanding protected classes to include marital status.  
   - Restricts nondisclosure provisions in employment and settlement agreements, requiring them to allow disclosure of discriminatory practices and imposing penalties for violations.  
   - Mandates employers maintain a detailed repository of all discrimination or harassment complaints, which may be used in litigation.  
   These changes strengthen employee protections against discrimination and harassment and increase employer recordkeeping obligations [1][2][3].

4. **Job Application Fairness Act (SB 23-058, effective July 1, 2024):**  
   - Prohibits employers from asking applicants for age, date of birth, or education attendance/graduation dates on initial job applications to reduce age discrimination risks.  
   - Violations can result in fines enforced by the CDLE [1][2][3].

5. **Other Notable Changes:**  
   - Minimum wage increased to $13.65 statewide as of January 1, 2023, with Denver setting a higher local minimum wage of $17.29.  
   - Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) program began January 1, 2024, providing up to 12 weeks of paid leave for qualifying reasons, funded by employee and employer contributions.  
   - Amendments to workers’ compensation, noncompete agreements, and protections related to natural hair discrimination (CROWN Act) also took effect or are scheduled for 2024 [2][3][4][5].

For small businesses, these laws mean updating job postings and internal notices, revising sick leave policies, enhancing anti-discrimination training and complaint tracking, and adjusting hiring practices to comply with new application restrictions. Employers should consult legal counsel to ensure compliance and avoid penalties as enforcement mechanisms become more robust [1][2][3][4].

---

**References:**  
[1] Colorado's New Employment Laws 2023 overview, including SB 23-105, SB 23-017, SB 23-172, and SB 23-058.  
[2] BHGR Law summary of 2023 Colorado employment law changes with effective dates and detailed provisions.  
[3] Colorado Dental Association Journal Winter 2025 article on 2024 amendments and new laws impacting employers.  
[4] Hackstaff, Snow, Atkinson & Griess, LLC 2023 employment law updates including minimum wage and noncompete changes.  
[5] Colorado Division of Labor Standards and Statistics wage and hour rules and minimum wage updates.  
[6] Summary of Colorado Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) paid sick leave provisions and recent amendments.

It also links to official Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) materials and offers best practices for compliance [Source 1].

2. **Mosey’s HFWA Guide** breaks down the law into actionable steps for employers, including eligibility (employees earning $2,500 in wages over four quarters), job protection after 180 days, accrual and carryover rules, permissible uses of leave, documentation limits, and coordination with other leave laws like FMLA. It emphasizes compliance risks, recordkeeping (minimum four years), and employer posting and notification duties. This guide is practical for HR professionals managing sick leave policies [Source 2].

3. **TCWGlobal Blog (2025 update)** offers a clear, employee- and employer-focused explanation of HFWA, including accrual, usage, public health emergency leave (up to 80 hours supplemental leave during declared emergencies), covered family members, employer responsibilities, exemptions, and common FAQs. It highlights the law’s broad coverage of all workers (full-time, part-time, temporary) and the importance of understanding how sick leave interacts with other policies [Source 3].

4. **Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) Fact Sheet** provides an official, up-to-date summary of HFWA’s provisions, including expanded reasons for leave effective August 2023 (bereavement, inclement weather-related closures, evacuation), detailed explanations of public health emergency leave, documentation rules, retaliation protections, and enforcement mechanisms. It also offers contact information for legal assistance and clarifies employer and employee rights [Source 4].

5. **CDLE Wage and Hour Laws Overview** includes the legal framework for paid sick leave under HFWA, enforcement authority, recordkeeping requirements, and links to official statutes, rules, and guidance documents. This resource is essential for understanding the regulatory and compliance environment in Colorado [Source 5].

6. **Colorado Legislative Summary of HFWA (SB20-205)** outlines the statutory basis for paid sick leave, accrual and usage rules, public health emergency leave specifics, employee eligibility, and employer obligations. It also clarifies that employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave at separation but must reinstate it if rehiring occurs within six months. This summary is useful for legal and policy reference [Source 6].

Together, these resources provide a thorough, expert-level understanding of Colorado paid sick leave law, covering legal requirements, practical implementation, employee rights, and employer responsibilities. For official and detailed guidance, the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment website and its published materials are indispensable. For practical HR and employer compliance advice, Justworks and Mosey guides are highly recommended. For employee-focused explanations and updates, TCWGlobal’s blog is valuable [Sources 1][2][3][4][5][6].

optimizations.query: new employee legal requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado implemented several key legal requirements for new employees and employers that affect hiring, pay, leave, and workplace protections:

1. **Equal Pay and Job Posting Requirements (SB 23-105, effective January 1, 2024):**  
   Employers must post job opportunities both internally and externally on the same day, including specific salary ranges, benefits descriptions, and application deadlines. This excludes routine career development or progression changes. After hiring, employers must notify employees who work closely with the new hire about the selected candidate’s name, former and new job titles, and how to express interest in similar future jobs. Employers with no physical presence in Colorado and fewer than 15 remote employees in the state have reduced posting obligations until July 1, 2029. The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) enforces these rules and will mediate wage discrimination complaints, with back pay recoverable up to six years for ongoing violations [1][2][4].

2. **Paid Sick Leave Expansion (SB 23-017, effective August 7, 2023):**  
   Under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually. The 2023 amendment expands allowable uses of paid sick leave to include grieving and attending funerals for family members, handling related legal or financial matters, caring for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events, and evacuating residences under similar conditions. Employers cannot retaliate against employees for taking such leave and may not require a doctor’s note until after four consecutive missed shifts [1][2][4][6].

3. **Anti-Discrimination and Harassment Law Updates (SB 23-172, effective August 7, 2023):**  
   The Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act broadens protections under the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act by redefining harassment standards, adding marital status as a protected class, and limiting employer defenses in discrimination claims. It restricts nondisclosure agreements in employment contracts, requiring them to allow disclosure of discriminatory practices and imposing penalties for violations. Employers must maintain a detailed repository of all discrimination or harassment complaints, which may be used in litigation [1][2][4].

4. **Job Application Fairness Act (SB 23-058, effective July 1, 2024):**  
   Employers are prohibited from asking applicants for age-related information on initial job applications, including age, date of birth, and school attendance or graduation dates. Exceptions exist for bona fide occupational qualifications or legal requirements. Violations may result in fines enforced by the CDLE [2][4].

5. **Other Important 2023 Changes:**  
   - Minimum wage increased to $13.65/hour statewide (higher in Denver) as of January 1, 2023 [3].  
   - Employers must provide up to three weeks of leave for Colorado National Guard training (HB 23-1045) [2].  
   - Public employees gained new workplace rights under the Public Employees’ Workplace Protection Act (SB 23-111) [2].  
   - Workers’ compensation benefits for mental impairment increased (HB 23-1076) [2].  
   - Employers must register for unemployment insurance accounts and report new hires within 20 days of hire or by the first payroll after hire [5].  
   - Employers must maintain workers’ compensation insurance and comply with employment verification laws [5].

6. **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Program:**  
   Starting January 1, 2024, Colorado’s FAMLI program provides paid family and medical leave benefits funded by employee and employer contributions. Employers must notify employees of their rights and comply with leave protections [4].

In summary, new employees in Colorado in 2023 and beyond are covered by expanded paid sick leave rights, stronger anti-discrimination protections, and enhanced transparency in job postings and hiring. Employers must comply with updated wage posting rules, leave laws, and recordkeeping requirements, while also preparing for the 2024 implementation of age-related application restrictions and the FAMLI program [1][2][3][4][5][6].

optimizations.final_answer:
The SHRM (Society for Human Resource Management) provides a comprehensive paid sick leave policy template and resources on its website under the "Topics & Tools" section, specifically within the "Policies" and "Tools & Samples" pages. This includes customizable sick leave policy templates that employers can adapt to their organizational needs, ensuring compliance with applicable laws and best practices [Source 1].

SHRM also offers guidance on navigating paid leave benefits and state requirements, helping HR professionals understand the complexities of paid sick leave laws across different jurisdictions. This resource is valuable for designing compliant and effective paid sick leave policies that align with both federal and state regulations [Source 2].

Additionally, SHRM’s 2024 Employee Benefits Survey highlights that leave benefits, including paid sick leave, remain a top priority for employers, with 81% rating them as very or extremely important. Most employers provide paid vacation, holiday, and sick leave, with 96% or more offering these benefits. Many combine vacation and sick leave into a single paid time off (PTO) bank, though this practice has slightly declined recently [Source 3].

For specific state-level paid sick leave policies, SHRM references and links to official state resources. For example, California requires employers to provide at least 5 days or 40 hours of paid sick leave annually starting January 1, 2024, with detailed rules on accrual, usage, and employee eligibility. Employers must comply with both state and local ordinances, providing the more generous benefit when differences exist [Source 4].

Similarly, New York City mandates paid safe and sick leave with varying hours based on employer size, plus a separate 20 hours of paid prenatal leave starting January 1, 2025. Employers must allow leave use as accrued, provide written policies, and may require documentation only after three consecutive days of leave [Source 5].

Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act requires employers to provide up to 48 hours of earned paid sick leave, accrued at a rate of one hour per 30 hours worked, with provisions for use related to illness, preventive care, family care, and public health emergencies. Employers may loan leave and must comply with specific notice and documentation rules [Source 6].

In summary, SHRM’s paid sick leave policy page offers templates, legal compliance guidance, and benchmarking data to help HR professionals craft effective paid sick leave policies tailored to their organizational and jurisdictional requirements. It also connects users to detailed state and local paid sick leave laws to ensure full compliance and best practices [Source 1][2][3][4][5][6].

optimizations.query: what are the new worker benefits requirements in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado introduced several significant new worker benefits requirements and employment law changes affecting both public and private sector employers:

1. **Expanded Paid Sick Leave Uses (Effective August 7, 2023):**  
   Under SB 23-017, employees may now use paid sick leave not only for their own illness but also to grieve the death of a family member, attend funerals or memorials, handle legal or financial matters after a family member’s death, care for a family member whose school or place of care is unexpectedly closed (due to weather, power loss, etc.), or evacuate their residence due to similar emergency events. Employers should update sick leave policies accordingly and cannot retaliate against employees for taking such leave [1][4].

2. **Increased Leave for Colorado National Guard Training (Effective March 10, 2023):**  
   HB 23-1045 extends leave for National Guard training from 15 days to three weeks annually for both public and private employees. Employees may use paid or unpaid leave, and public employees no longer need to be mentally or physically able to be reinstated after leave [1].

3. **Public Employees’ Workplace Protection Act (Effective August 7, 2023, with some provisions July 1, 2024):**  
   This law grants public employees rights to discuss workplace issues, join employee organizations, and participate politically off duty, with protections against employer retaliation. It applies to a broad range of public entities and is enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment [1].

4. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act (Effective August 7, 2023):**  
   POWR expands anti-discrimination protections, redefines harassment, adds marital status as a protected class, modifies employer defenses in discrimination claims, voids certain nondisclosure agreements, and imposes new recordkeeping requirements. Employers should revise policies and agreements to comply [1][4].

5. **Workers’ Compensation Amendments (Effective 2023):**  
   HB 23-1076 increases medical impairment benefits for mental impairments from 12 to 36 weeks [1].

6. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (Effective January 1, 2024):**  
   SB 23-105 requires employers to post detailed job opportunity notices including compensation ranges, benefits, and application deadlines both internally and externally on the day a candidate is considered. Employers must also disclose selected candidates’ information to coworkers and provide transparency on career progression opportunities. The statute of limitations for wage claims extends to six years, and enforcement is handled by the State Division of Labor Standards and Statistics [1][4][5].

7. **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA) (Effective July 1, 2024):**  
   JAFA prohibits employers from requesting age, date of birth, or education attendance/graduation dates on initial job applications to reduce age discrimination. Employers may still verify age for legal compliance but cannot ask for this information upfront. Violations can result in fines enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment [1][4][5].

8. **Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Act (Effective January 1, 2024):**  
   Colorado’s paid family and medical leave program allows eligible employees up to 12 weeks of paid leave (16 weeks for pregnancy/childbirth complications) for bonding with a new child, serious health conditions, caregiving, military family needs, or domestic violence impacts. Both employers and employees contribute premiums. Job protection is guaranteed after six months of employment [4][5].

9. **Pregnant Workers Fairness Act (Effective June 27, 2023):**  
   Employers must provide reasonable accommodations for pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions unless it causes undue hardship. Failure to accommodate is considered discrimination [2].

10. **Provide Urgent Maternal Protections for Nursing Mothers Act (PUMP) (Effective April 28, 2023):**  
    Expands the right to break time and a private space for nursing mothers to pump breast milk at work, removing prior restrictions that limited this right to non-exempt employees [2].

11. **Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) Amendments:**  
    Employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, usable for personal or family illness, domestic violence recovery, or public health emergencies. Employers cannot require a doctor’s note until after four consecutive missed shifts and must allow carryover of unused leave. The law also provides supplemental leave during public health emergencies like COVID-19 [1][4][6].

12. **Agricultural Worker Protections:**  
    New overtime rules apply to agricultural employees with overtime eligibility starting at 48-56 hours depending on season and employer size. Paid breaks and water/shade requirements are mandated when temperatures exceed 80 degrees [2][5].

13. **Minimum Wage Increase (Effective January 1, 2024):**  
    The minimum wage rises to $14.46 per hour statewide, with specific rules for tipped employees, minors, and agricultural workers [2][5].

14. **Other Notable Changes Effective 2024 and Beyond:**  
    - Amendments to noncompete agreements enforcement and penalties (effective August 7, 2024)  
    - Expansion of the CROWN Act to prohibit discrimination based on hair length (effective August 7, 2024)  
    - Establishment of the Colorado Disability Opportunity Office to enhance protections for disabled workers (effective July 1, 2024)  
    - New biometric data privacy requirements for employers collecting such data (effective July 1, 2025) [4].

Employers in Colorado should review and update their policies, job postings, leave administration, and compliance procedures to align with these new requirements to avoid penalties and support employee rights effectively [1][4][5].

**In summary, Colorado’s 2023 worker benefits requirements emphasize expanded paid leave uses, enhanced anti-discrimination protections, pay transparency, family leave insurance, and stronger accommodations for pregnancy and nursing mothers, alongside wage and hour updates, reflecting the state’s progressive approach to worker rights and benefits.**

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.  

### Recordkeeping  
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.  

### Anti-Retaliation  
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.  
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.  

### Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated  
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up to 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.  
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.  

### Employee Handbook Templates and Resources  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA, including updating policies related to paid sick leave, employee handbook templates are widely available for purchase and customization. These templates typically include comprehensive language that aligns with HFWA requirements, covering accrual, usage, carryover, public health emergency leave provisions, notice procedures, and anti-retaliation protections. Employers can customize these templates to fit their specific workplace needs, ensuring consistent communication of paid sick leave policies to employees and streamlining compliance efforts.  

Common sources for purchasing employee handbook templates include reputable platforms such as SHRM, LegalZoom, Business-in-a-Box, HR360, and other HR service providers or legal firms specializing in employment law. Pricing for these templates generally ranges from approximately $50 to several hundred dollars, depending on the level of detail, customization options, and whether ongoing updates or legal reviews are included. Some providers offer state-specific or industry-specific templates tailored to meet unique regulatory requirements, including those of Colorado’s HFWA. Templates are commonly available in editable formats such as Microsoft Word and PDF, allowing employers to easily modify content to suit their organizational needs.  

Examples of template content relevant to HFWA compliance include sections on:  
- Paid sick leave accrual rates and caps  
- Procedures for requesting and documenting leave  
- Supplemental leave provisions during public health emergencies  
- Anti-retaliation policies protecting employees who use leave  
- Employer recordkeeping and notice obligations  

Employers should carefully evaluate templates to ensure they reflect the most current HFWA rules and any related state or federal laws. Customization options often allow employers to add company-specific procedures or integrate the leave policy with broader workplace health and safety policies. Additionally, some providers offer free or low-cost basic templates that can serve as a starting point, though professionally developed templates typically provide more comprehensive coverage and reduce compliance risk.  

Utilizing these resources can reduce the risk of inadvertent violations and help employers maintain compliance with Colorado’s paid sick leave laws. optimizations.query: current state laws on mandatory sick leave for businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
As of early 2025, there is no federal law mandating paid sick leave for private employers in the United States; instead, paid sick leave requirements are governed at the state and local levels [1][5]. Currently, **17 states plus Washington, D.C.** have mandatory paid sick leave laws, including Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska, Nevada, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington, and Washington, D.C. [1][5].

These state laws vary significantly in terms of accrual rates, usage caps, covered employers, and qualifying reasons for leave. For example:

- **Accrual rates** typically range from 1 hour of paid sick leave earned per 30 to 52 hours worked.
- **Annual caps** on usage vary widely, generally between 24 and 72 hours depending on the state and employer size.
- **Covered employers** may be defined by number of employees, with some states phasing in requirements for smaller employers over time (e.g., Connecticut expanding coverage to employers with 11+ employees in 2026 and all employers in 2027) [1][5].
- **Qualifying reasons** for leave often include the employee’s own illness, caring for family members, domestic violence-related needs, and public health emergencies, though the scope differs by state [1][6].

For instance, Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act requires all employers to provide up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, accrued at 1 hour per 30 hours worked, with leave usable for a broad range of health and safety reasons including mental health, domestic violence recovery, and public health emergencies [1][6]. California mandates 40 hours (5 days) of paid sick leave per year, accrued similarly, with narrowly defined eligible reasons but includes domestic violence and stalking [1]. Arizona also requires 40 hours per year with broad family member definitions and use reasons [1].

Employers must carefully track accruals, usage, and comply with carryover rules (most states require unused leave to carry over to the next year, though usage caps may apply). Many states prohibit “use it or lose it” policies and restrict requiring doctor’s notes for short absences [1][5].

In summary, while no federal mandate exists, a growing number of states require private employers to provide paid sick leave with diverse rules. Employers operating in multiple states face complex compliance challenges and should review each applicable statute carefully to ensure adherence [1][5].

**Key points:**

- No federal paid sick leave mandate for private employers; state/local laws apply.
- 17+ states plus D.C. have mandatory paid sick leave laws as of 2025.
- Accrual rates generally 1 hour per 30-52 hours worked; annual caps 24-72 hours.
- Covered employers vary by state; some phase in smaller employers over time.
- Qualifying reasons include employee/family illness, domestic violence, public health emergencies.
- Carryover of unused leave is generally required; usage caps apply.
- Employers must maintain records and avoid common compliance pitfalls like requiring doctor’s notes unnecessarily or applying uniform policies across states without adjustments [1][5][6].

This patchwork of laws requires employers to stay informed and implement tailored policies to remain compliant and support employee health [1][5].

optimizations.query: current trends in worker benefits 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, key trends in worker benefits reflect a strong focus on holistic employee well-being, cost management, flexibility, and family support, driven by ongoing economic uncertainty, labor market challenges, and the lasting impact of the pandemic.

1. **Employee Well-being and Mental Health**: Employers are increasingly prioritizing mental health benefits to address elevated stress, burnout, and poor mental health among workers. This includes expanding employee assistance programs, offering online mental health resources, training managers to recognize behavioral issues, and promoting workplace flexibility to support work-life balance [3][5]. Addressing cumulative stress—stemming from both work and personal life—is recognized as critical, with employers encouraged to foster open communication and manager training to prevent burnout and turnover [2].

2. **Health Care Cost Management**: Controlling rising health care costs remains a priority. Employers are adopting strategies such as telemedicine, modifying health plan designs, improving health care literacy, using analytics, and incentivizing cost-effective care choices to keep benefits affordable while maintaining quality [3].

3. **Voluntary and Family-Friendly Benefits**: There is growing adoption of voluntary benefits that employees can choose based on their needs, including critical illness, accident, pet insurance, student loan repayment assistance, and identity theft protection. Family-friendly benefits are also expanding, with more employers offering paid parental leave, adoption leave, surrogacy benefits, and support for pregnancy, lactation, postpartum, and menopause care [3][5].

4. **Flexible Work Arrangements**: Remote and hybrid work options continue to be important for improving employee mental health and work-life balance, while also helping employers reduce overhead and access a broader talent pool [3].

5. **Pay Transparency and Communication**: Pay transparency is becoming more common, helping employers attract applicants and reduce recruitment costs by setting clear expectations. Additionally, fostering candid communication between managers and employees is seen as essential to identify and mitigate stress and burnout early [3][2].

6. **Addressing Cumulative Stress and Burnout**: Employers are urged to consider the totality of stressors affecting employees, including financial, social, and health-related pressures outside of work. Proactive management through workload adjustments and supportive dialogue is key to maintaining productivity and engagement [2].

7. **Legislative and Policy Developments**: Some regions, such as Colorado, have enacted laws requiring paid sick leave with broad eligibility and usage provisions, including for mental health and family care, reflecting a trend toward more comprehensive statutory benefits [6].

Overall, 2023 worker benefits trends emphasize a comprehensive, flexible, and employee-centered approach that balances cost control with meaningful support for mental health, family needs, and work-life integration, aiming to enhance employee satisfaction, retention, and organizational success [1][2][3][5].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.  

### Recordkeeping  
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.  

### Anti-Retaliation  
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.  

### Notice to Employees  
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.  
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.  

### Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated  
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up to 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.  
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.  

### Employee Handbook Templates and Resources  
To assist employers in complying with the HFWA, including updating policies related to paid sick leave, employee handbook templates are widely available for purchase and customization. These templates typically include comprehensive language that aligns with HFWA requirements, covering accrual, usage, carryover, public health emergency leave provisions, notice procedures, and anti-retaliation protections. Employers can customize these templates to fit their specific workplace needs, ensuring consistent communication of paid sick leave policies to employees and streamlining compliance efforts.  

Common sources for purchasing employee handbook templates include reputable platforms such as SHRM, LegalZoom, Business-in-a-Box, HR360, and other HR service providers or legal firms specializing in employment law. Pricing for these templates generally ranges from approximately $50 to several hundred dollars, depending on the level of detail, customization options, and whether ongoing updates or legal reviews are included. Some providers offer state-specific or industry-specific templates tailored to meet unique regulatory requirements, including those of Colorado’s HFWA. Templates are commonly available in editable formats such as Microsoft Word and PDF, allowing employers to easily modify content to suit their organizational needs.  

Examples of template content relevant to HFWA compliance include sections on:  
- Paid sick leave accrual rates and caps  
- Procedures for requesting and documenting leave  
- Supplemental leave provisions during public health emergencies  
- Anti-retaliation policies protecting employees who use leave  
- Employer recordkeeping and notice obligations  

Employers should carefully evaluate templates to ensure they reflect the most current HFWA rules and any related state or federal laws. Customization options often allow employers to add company-specific procedures or integrate the leave policy with broader workplace health and safety policies. Additionally, some providers offer free or low-cost basic templates that can serve as a starting point, though professionally developed templates typically provide more comprehensive coverage and reduce compliance risk.  

Utilizing these resources can reduce the risk of inadvertent violations and help employers maintain compliance with Colorado’s paid sick leave laws. Employers are encouraged to contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom they regularly work for guidance.

optimizations.query: what are the new sick leave requirements for businesses in colorado?
optimizations.final_answer:
The new sick leave requirements for businesses in Colorado are governed by the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates that all employers, regardless of size, provide paid sick leave to their employees starting January 1, 2022. Employees accrue one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours (6 days) per year, with unused leave carrying over to the next year but usage capped at 48 hours annually. Employers may also frontload the full 48 hours at the start of the year instead of accrual. Sick leave can be used for a broad range of reasons including the employee’s own physical or mental illness, preventive care, caring for family members (including children, spouses, parents, grandparents, siblings, and others with a significant personal bond), domestic violence or sexual assault-related needs, and public health emergencies such as business or school closures ordered by public officials [3][4][6].

In addition to accrued sick leave, during declared public health emergencies, employees are entitled to supplemental paid sick leave of up to 80 hours (pro-rated for part-time workers). This supplemental leave covers COVID-19 and other communicable illnesses, including self-isolation, medical care, preventive care, and caring for family members affected by the emergency. Employers cannot require documentation for this leave, and it remains available for up to four weeks after the emergency ends [3][4][6].

Employers must provide notice of employee rights under HFWA, maintain records of hours worked and leave used for at least two years, and are prohibited from retaliating against employees for using sick leave. Employees begin accruing sick leave immediately upon hire and may use it as it accrues. Employers may not require employees to find replacement workers as a condition for taking leave, and leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments [3][6].

Recent amendments effective August 7, 2023, expanded qualifying reasons for sick leave to include time to grieve or handle matters following a family member’s death, care for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events, and evacuation due to such events [4].

In summary, Colorado’s sick leave law requires all employers to provide paid sick leave accrued at one hour per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, with broad usage rights including physical and mental health, family care, domestic violence, and public health emergencies, plus supplemental leave during declared emergencies. Employers must comply with notice, recordkeeping, and anti-retaliation provisions to ensure employee protections under HFWA [3][4][6].
