Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:

Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.

The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.

An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

optimizations.query: what are the mandatory sick leave laws in colorado for small businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
In Colorado, the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) mandates paid sick leave for all employers, including small businesses, with specific phased implementation and detailed requirements:

1. **Applicability by Employer Size and Timeline**:  
   - From January 1, 2021, employers with 16 or more employees must provide paid sick leave.  
   - Starting January 1, 2022, this requirement extends to all employers regardless of size, including small businesses with fewer than 16 employees [1][2][6].

2. **Accrual and Usage**:  
   - Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire, earning at least 1 hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked.  
   - Accrual caps at 48 hours per year unless the employer allows more.  
   - Employees may use accrued sick leave as it is earned and can carry over up to 48 hours of unused leave to the next year, though employers may limit annual usage to 48 hours [1][2][3][6].

3. **Permitted Reasons for Leave**:  
   Paid sick leave can be used for:  
   - The employee’s own physical or mental illness, injury, health condition, medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
   - Caring for a family member with similar health needs.  
   - Situations involving domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment, including medical attention, counseling, legal services, or relocation.  
   - Closure of the employee’s workplace or their child’s school/place of care due to a public health emergency, requiring the employee to care for the child [1][2][6].

4. **Public Health Emergency (PHE) Leave**:  
   - In addition to accrued sick leave, during a declared public health emergency (such as COVID-19), all employers must provide supplemental paid sick leave (up to 80 hours for full-time employees, prorated for part-time).  
   - This leave covers self-isolation, symptoms, medical care, preventive care, care for exposed family members, childcare disruptions, or increased susceptibility to illness.  
   - Employers cannot require documentation for PHE leave and must allow use until four weeks after the emergency ends [2][5][6].

5. **Usage and Documentation**:  
   - Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer permits smaller increments.  
   - Employers may require reasonable documentation only if the employee takes four or more consecutive days of accrued sick leave, but not for PHE leave.  
   - Employees cannot be required to find a replacement worker as a condition for taking leave [2][3][6].

6. **Job Protection and Anti-Retaliation**:  
   - Job protection against retaliation applies after 180 days of employment, preventing adverse actions for legitimate use of sick leave.  
   - Employers must maintain records of accrual and usage for at least three to four years and provide written notice of rights to employees [3][4].

7. **Separation and Rehire**:  
   - Employers are not required to pay out unused accrued sick leave upon separation.  
   - If an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate any unused accrued sick leave from prior employment unless it was paid out [1][6].

In summary, Colorado’s mandatory sick leave laws require all employers, including small businesses, to provide paid sick leave accrued at a rate of 1 hour per 30 hours worked, with a 48-hour annual cap, usable for a broad range of health and safety reasons, including during public health emergencies. Employers must comply with accrual, usage, documentation, and anti-retaliation provisions to avoid penalties [1][2][3][5][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:

Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

optimizations.final_answer:
Colorado labor laws for employee benefits require employers to comply with both federal and state-specific regulations that provide a range of protections and benefits to employees. Key points include:

1. **Paid Sick Leave**: Under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), all Colorado employers must provide paid sick leave. Employees accrue at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year. This leave can be used for personal or family illness, preventive care, or issues related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment. Employers must also provide supplemental paid sick leave during public health emergencies, such as COVID-19, with up to 80 hours available for qualifying reasons. Employers cannot require employees to find replacement workers to take leave, and unused leave can carry over up to 48 hours annually, though usage may be capped at 48 hours per year. There is no payout of unused sick leave at separation unless the employee is rehired within six months, in which case accrued leave must be reinstated [6][2].

2. **Wage and Hour Laws**: Employers must pay at least the state minimum wage (which will increase to $15.16/hour on January 1, 2026) and comply with overtime pay requirements. Employees are entitled to meal breaks (30 minutes for every five hours worked) and paid rest breaks (10 minutes every four hours). Employers cannot make impermissible deductions from wages and must pay all earned wages timely [2][5].

3. **Equal Pay and Anti-Discrimination**: Colorado’s Equal Pay for Equal Work Act mandates equal pay and benefits for employees performing substantially similar work, with limited exceptions. The Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act (CADA) prohibits discrimination based on protected classes including race, gender, sexual orientation, disability, and now explicitly includes gender expression. Employers must update policies accordingly [1][5].

4. **Family and Medical Leave**: The Colorado Paid Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Act provides paid family and medical leave benefits, including an expansion allowing up to an additional 12 weeks of leave if a newborn requires NICU care. Employers with 10 or more employees share premium costs with employees [5].

5. **Workplace Accommodations**: Employers must provide reasonable accommodations for nursing mothers, including breaks and private spaces (not bathrooms) for expressing breast milk for up to two years after childbirth [1].

6. **Employee Rights**: Employees have rights to access personnel files, discuss wages freely, and protections against retaliation for whistleblowing or reporting workplace violations. Colorado is an at-will employment state but prohibits termination for illegal reasons [1].

7. **State Employee Benefits**: For state employees, benefits include medical, dental, vision, life insurance, disability, and wellness programs. Coverage extends to eligible dependents, with enrollment periods and qualifying life event rules. Some changes for FY 2025-26 include increased premiums and changes to coverage for certain obesity drugs (GLP-1s) [3].

In summary, Colorado labor laws provide comprehensive employee benefits protections including paid sick leave, fair wages, anti-discrimination safeguards, family leave, and workplace accommodations. Employers must stay current with evolving laws such as minimum wage increases and new AI-related employment regulations effective in 2026 [1][2][3][5][6].

In 2023, Colorado enacted several significant labor law changes affecting employers and employees statewide, effective primarily as of August 7, 2023, with some provisions starting earlier or later. Key updates include:

1. **Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act (SB 23-172):**  
   - Revises the definition of unlawful workplace harassment by lowering the standard from the federal "severe and pervasive" to any unwelcome conduct that is subjectively and objectively offensive based on protected class status.  
   - Expands discrimination protections to include marital status.  
   - Imposes new restrictions on nondisclosure agreements (NDAs) in employment, requiring that NDAs not prevent employees from disclosing discriminatory practices and mandating equal application to all parties.  
   - Requires employers to maintain a repository of all discrimination and harassment complaints, including oral and written reports, with detailed records kept as personnel files.  
   - Violations of NDA provisions can result in damages of $5,000 per violation [1][5].

2. **Job Application Fairness Act (JAFA):**  
   - Prohibits employers from asking about an applicant’s age on initial job applications to reduce age discrimination [1][5].

3. **Amendments to the Colorado Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA):**  
   - Expands reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave to include grieving family deaths, attending funerals, dealing with related financial/legal matters, caring for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events, and evacuations for similar reasons.  
   - Employers must provide at least one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, with a cap of 48 hours per year, and allow carryover of unused leave.  
   - Paid sick leave can be used in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.  
   - The law also includes provisions related to public health emergencies, supplementing leave for COVID-19 and similar events [1][5][6].

4. **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (SB 23-105):**  
   - Narrows internal job posting requirements by excluding in-line career progression opportunities from mandatory postings.  
   - Expands employer obligations to notify employees about job selections, including the name and job title of the selected candidate and how employees can apply for similar future opportunities.  
   - Enhances enforcement by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE), including a new mediation process for sex-based wage discrimination claims starting July 1, 2024.  
   - Extends the back pay recovery period for wage discrimination claims up to six years [1][5].

5. **Minimum Wage Increase:**  
   - Effective January 1, 2023, Colorado’s minimum wage rose to $13.65 per hour for regular employees and $10.63 for tipped employees, reflecting a roughly 9% inflation-based increase. Denver’s minimum wage is higher at $17.29 per hour [3].

6. **Paid Family & Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Program:**  
   - Starting in 2023, private employers must begin payroll deductions to fund the state’s paid family leave program, which provides up to 12 weeks of paid leave for parental bonding, medical care, military exigencies, and safe leave related to domestic violence. Employers may opt to offer compliant alternative plans [2][3].

7. **Non-Compete Law Changes:**  
   - Colorado limits enforceability of non-compete and non-solicitation agreements, especially for employees earning below specified salary thresholds ($101,250 for non-competes, $60,750 for non-solicitation).  
   - Penalties for violations increased to $5,000 per violation [2][3].

8. **Unemployment Insurance Wage Base Increase:**  
   - The wage base for unemployment insurance premiums increased from $17,000 in 2022 to $20,400 in 2023, with scheduled increases through 2026 to replenish the state’s unemployment trust fund [3].

These laws apply to private employers with at least one employee in Colorado and reflect the state’s ongoing efforts to enhance worker protections, promote pay equity, and regulate employment agreements more strictly. Employers are advised to review and update policies accordingly to ensure compliance [1][2][3][5][6].

For detailed guidance, employers should consult legal counsel or the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment resources.

---

**References:**  
[1] Epstein Becker Green, "Colorado Enacts Significant New Employment Laws," 2023  
[2] Jones & Keller, "Changes in Labor and Employment Laws from 2018 to 2023," Jan 2024  
[3] Hackstaff, Snow, Atkinson & Griess, LLC, "Top Colorado Employment Law Updates for 2023"  
[5] Colorado Legislative Summary, "Colorado's New Employment Laws: What to Know (2023)"  
[6] Colorado Healthy Families and Workplaces Act Summary

optimizations.query: overview of colorado paid sick leave law for businesses
optimizations.final_answer:
Colorado’s paid sick leave law, known as the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), requires all employers to provide paid sick leave to employees, with phased implementation based on employer size: employers with 16 or more employees since January 1, 2021, and all employers regardless of size since January 1, 2022 [3][5][6].  

Employees accrue paid sick leave at a rate of 1 hour for every 30 hours worked, up to a maximum of 48 hours per year, which can be carried over year to year, though employers may limit annual usage to 48 hours [2][4][5][6]. Accrual begins immediately upon hire, and employees may use accrued leave as it is earned without a waiting period [5][6]. Employers may alternatively front-load 48 hours at the start of the year instead of tracking accrual [2].  

Paid sick leave can be used for a broad range of reasons including the employee’s own physical or mental illness, injury, or preventive care; caring for a family member with similar health needs; recovery or services related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; and absences due to public health emergencies such as workplace or school closures [3][4][5][6]. The law also covers leave for additional purposes added in 2023, such as grieving a family member’s death or responding to closures caused by inclement weather or other unexpected events [4].  

Employees become eligible for job protection from retaliation after 180 days of continuous employment, meaning employers cannot discipline or terminate employees for taking legitimate paid sick leave after this period [2]. Employers must maintain records of hours worked, leave accrued, and leave used for at least three to four years and provide written notice of rights and accrual balances to employees, including posting official notices [2][3][6].  

During declared public health emergencies, employers must provide supplemental Public Health Emergency (PHE) leave, ensuring employees have access to up to 80 hours of paid leave (or a pro-rated amount for part-time workers) for COVID-19 or similar health crises, regardless of accrual status. This PHE leave is available until four weeks after the emergency ends and cannot require documentation for use [3][5][6].  

Employers must coordinate HFWA leave with other leave policies such as FMLA and PTO, ensuring that PTO policies do not restrict the use of paid sick leave under HFWA [2][5]. Misclassification of employees, improper accrual calculations, excessive documentation demands, and retaliation are common compliance pitfalls that can lead to significant penalties starting at $50 per violation and escalating for willful or repeated offenses [2].  

In summary, Colorado’s paid sick leave law mandates that all employers provide accrued paid sick leave at a minimum rate of 1 hour per 30 hours worked, with broad usage rights, job protection after 180 days, supplemental leave during public health emergencies, and strict recordkeeping and notice requirements enforced by the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment [1][2][3][4][5][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.

optimizations.query: overview of new sick leave laws in colorado 2023
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado expanded its paid sick leave law under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) through Senate Bill 23-017, signed by Governor Jared Polis on June 2, 2023, with the amendments effective August 7, 2023 [1][2][3][6].

Key changes include broadening the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave. Beyond the original uses—such as personal or family illness, preventive care, domestic abuse recovery, and closures due to public health emergencies—employees can now also use paid sick leave for:

1. Bereavement: grieving, attending funerals or memorials, and handling financial or legal matters after the death of a family member.
2. Caring for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events.
3. Evacuating their residence due to inclement weather, loss of power, heating, water, or other unexpected events [1][2][3][6].

Additionally, the supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended on June 9, 2023, so employers are no longer required to provide this leave [1][2][6].

Employers must update their sick leave policies and workplace posters to reflect these new provisions by the effective date and notify employees of their expanded rights under the HFWA [1][2][3][6].

It is important to distinguish HFWA from Colorado’s Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) program, which began coverage in 2024. HFWA requires employers to pay employees their full wages for sick leave hours taken, while FAMLI provides partial wage replacement funded by both employers and employees through a state-managed insurance program. FAMLI covers serious health conditions and family care but does not cover bereavement or inclement weather-related leave. Employees cannot receive HFWA and FAMLI benefits simultaneously for the same hours but may use HFWA leave to supplement FAMLI benefits up to 100% of their wages [4][5].

In summary, the 2023 HFWA amendments in Colorado expand paid sick leave usage to include bereavement and weather-related events, end COVID-19 supplemental leave, and require employers to update policies and employee notifications accordingly [1][2][3][6]. This expansion enhances employee protections and clarifies the interplay between HFWA and FAMLI leave programs [4][5].

The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;

In Colorado, paid sick leave for small businesses is governed by the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which requires all employers, regardless of size, to provide paid sick leave to their employees starting January 1, 2022. This means even small businesses must comply with the law’s provisions [1][3][4][6].

**Accrual and Usage:** Employees accrue one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to a maximum of 48 hours (6 days) per year. Accrual begins immediately on the first day of employment, and employees may use sick leave as it is accrued. Employers can also choose to frontload the full 48 hours at the start of the year instead of tracking accrual [1][3][4][6].

**Permitted Uses:** Paid sick leave can be used for a broad range of reasons including the employee’s own physical or mental illness, injury, or preventive care; caring for a family member with similar health needs; and for issues related to domestic violence, sexual assault, or harassment. Family members covered include children (biological, adopted, foster, or stepchildren), spouses or domestic partners, parents, grandparents, grandchildren, and siblings. Additionally, leave can be used during public health emergencies for reasons such as quarantine, testing, or vaccination, and for school or workplace closures [1][3][4][5][6].

**Additional Leave for Public Health Emergencies:** Beyond the standard accrued sick leave, during declared public health emergencies, employees are entitled to supplemental paid sick leave—up to 80 hours for full-time employees or a prorated amount for part-time workers. This leave covers COVID-19 and other similar emergencies but the supplemental leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023 [1][4][6].

**Carryover and Limits:** Unused sick leave can be carried over to the next year, but employers may limit the use to 48 hours annually. Employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave upon termination, but if an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate the unused leave unless it was paid out at separation [1][3][4][6].

**Employer Obligations:** Employers must notify employees of their rights under HFWA through posters and written notices, keep records of hours worked and sick leave used for at least two years, and are prohibited from retaliating against employees for using sick leave. Employers may require reasonable documentation for absences of four or more consecutive days but cannot demand disclosure of the medical condition [1][3][4][6].

**Small Business Impact:** Initially, only employers with 16 or more employees were required to provide paid sick leave starting in 2021, but since 2022, all employers, including small businesses, must comply. This law ensures that small businesses provide the same paid sick leave benefits as larger employers, leveling the playing field and promoting employee well-being [3][4][6].

In summary, small businesses in Colorado must provide paid sick leave accruing at one hour per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours annually, usable for a wide range of health and safety reasons, with additional protections during public health emergencies. Employers must maintain compliance through proper notification, recordkeeping, and non-retaliation policies [1][3][4][5][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

In addition, effective August 7, 2023, Colorado expanded the HFWA via Senate Bill 23-017 to broaden the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave. These new reasons include:  
- Bereavement leave to grieve or attend funeral services of a family member;  
- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.  

Employers are required to notify employees of these new rights and update their paid sick leave policies and workplace posters accordingly. Colorado is expected to publish updated official posters reflecting these amendments. Employers should ensure their sick leave policies and posters reflect these changes by the effective date.  

The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies to reflect this termination.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.

Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.

The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.

Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.

Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.

An employee’s need to:

(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:

(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;

Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.

The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;

(i) The employee’s place of business; or
