Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

In addition, effective August 7, 2023, Colorado expanded the HFWA via Senate Bill 23-017 to broaden the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave. These new reasons include:  
- Bereavement leave to grieve or attend funeral services of a family member;  
- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.  

Employers are required to notify employees of these new rights and update their paid sick leave policies and workplace posters accordingly. Colorado is expected to publish updated official posters reflecting these amendments. Employers should ensure their sick leave policies and posters reflect these changes by the effective date.  

The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies to reflect this termination.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.  

*Note: The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies accordingly.*  

### Recordkeeping  
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.  

### Anti-Retaliation  
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.  

### Notice to Employees  
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.  
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.

Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up to 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.  
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.

optimizations.final_answer:
The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) oversees the state's paid sick leave requirements under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA). Under this law, most Colorado employees accrue paid sick leave at a rate of at least one hour per 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, which can be used for various health-related reasons including the employee’s own illness, preventive care, or caring for a family member, as well as for situations involving domestic abuse, sexual assault, or public health emergencies [1][2][6].

Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused sick leave into the next year, but employers can limit annual use to 48 hours. Importantly, the CDLE clarified that carried-over hours count toward the accrual cap in the following year, meaning an employee who carries over the full 48 hours does not accrue additional hours that year [1]. 

During a declared public health emergency, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, employees are entitled to supplemental Public Health Emergency Leave (PHEL) of up to 80 hours, which employers can offset by any accrued but unused sick leave at the time of the leave request. Employees must use the supplemental leave first before drawing on accrued sick leave [1][6].

Paid sick leave must be paid at the employee’s regular rate of pay and can be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments. Employers may require reasonable documentation after four consecutive days of leave and must provide written notice of employee rights and display official posters about the HFWA [2][6].

The HFWA does not require payout of unused sick leave upon separation, but if an employee is rehired within six months, their unused accrued leave must be reinstated. Employers must update policies to reflect recent expansions of leave reasons, including bereavement and leave due to inclement weather or emergency evacuations [6].

For detailed official guidance, including the CDLE’s Interpretive Notice #6B and updated employer obligations, visit the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment website or their published INFO documents [1][4].

In summary, Colorado’s Department of Labor provides comprehensive guidance on paid sick leave accrual, usage, carryover, and public health emergency leave under the HFWA, ensuring employees have access to paid leave for a broad range of health and safety needs while clarifying employer responsibilities [1][2][6].

Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.

Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.

Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;

(i) The employee’s place of business; or

As of early 2025, paid sick leave compliance in the United States is governed primarily at the state and local levels, as there is no overarching federal paid sick leave law for private employers. Currently, 15 states plus Washington, D.C., have mandatory paid sick leave laws, each with specific accrual rates, usage limits, and covered reasons for leave. Additionally, three states mandate paid leave for any reason, broadening the scope beyond just sickness [1].

Key features of state paid sick leave laws include:

- **Accrual and Usage:** Most states require employees to accrue paid sick leave at a rate of 1 hour per 30 hours worked, with annual usage caps typically ranging from 40 to 48 hours. For example, Arizona and California both mandate accrual at 1 hour per 30 hours worked with a maximum annual use of 40 hours, while Colorado allows up to 48 hours per year [1][6].

- **Covered Reasons for Leave:** Eligible reasons generally include the employee’s own illness, preventive care, and caring for family members. Some states extend coverage to issues related to domestic violence, stalking, public health emergencies, bereavement, and mental health wellness days. Colorado, for instance, expanded its law in 2023 to include bereavement leave and leave due to inclement weather or utility loss [1][6].

- **Family Member Definitions:** States vary in defining family members covered under paid sick leave. California’s law includes a broad range of family members such as biological, adopted, foster, stepchildren, grandparents, siblings, and even a designated person chosen by the employee. Arizona and Colorado similarly have expansive definitions including persons related by blood, marriage, or close association [1][6].

- **Employer Coverage and Size Thresholds:** Some states apply paid sick leave laws only to employers above certain size thresholds, which may phase in over time. Connecticut, for example, currently applies its law to employers with 25 or more employees but will lower this threshold to 1 employee by 2027 [1].

- **Local Ordinances and Preemption:** In states like California, local paid sick leave ordinances may impose additional requirements. Employers must comply with both state and local laws, providing the more generous benefit to employees. However, as of 2024, certain state law provisions preempt conflicting local rules regarding accrual, paystub statements, and payment timing [1][5].

- **Exemptions and Special Cases:** Some employees are exempt or partially exempt, such as certain unionized workers under qualifying collective bargaining agreements or specific industries like air carriers and railroads. Employers with such agreements must still comply with key provisions like anti-retaliation and allowing oral or written leave requests [5].

- **Carryover and Separation:** Most states require unused accrued sick leave to carry over to the next year, though employers may cap the amount of leave used annually. Payment of unused sick leave upon separation is generally not required, except in cases of retaliation or if the employee is rehired within a specified period (e.g., six months in Colorado) [1][6].

- **Public Health Emergency Leave:** Some states, including Colorado, have provisions for supplemental paid sick leave related to public health emergencies like COVID-19, providing additional leave beyond regular accruals. These provisions may have sunset dates and require policy updates by employers [6].

In summary, compliance with paid sick leave laws requires employers to carefully track accruals, usage, covered reasons, and family member definitions according to each applicable state and local law. Employers operating in multiple jurisdictions face complex challenges due to varying thresholds, definitions, and overlapping local ordinances. Staying current with annual updates and posting required notices is essential to maintain compliance and avoid penalties [1][5][6].

**References:**  
[1] GovDocs, "Paid Sick Leave Laws by State," updated February 2025  
[5] California Department of Industrial Relations, Paid Sick Leave FAQs, updated December 2025  
[6] Colorado Healthy Families and Workplaces Act details, updated 2023

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.

The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.

(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

- Bereavement leave to grieve or attend funeral services of a family member;  
- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.

Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.

Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.

optimizations.query: what are the new sick leave requirements in colorado for 2023?
optimizations.final_answer:
In 2023, Colorado expanded its paid sick leave requirements under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA) through Senate Bill 23-017, effective August 7, 2023. The key changes broaden the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave beyond the original health-related purposes. Previously, employees could use paid sick leave for their own or a family member’s mental or physical illness, preventive medical care, recovery from domestic abuse or harassment, and closures due to public health emergencies. The 2023 amendments add the following new qualifying reasons for paid sick leave use:

1. Bereavement leave to grieve, attend funeral or memorial services, or handle financial and legal matters following the death of a family member.
2. Care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather, loss of utilities (power, heating, water), or other unexpected events.
3. Evacuation of the employee’s residence due to inclement weather, utility loss, or other unexpected events [1][2][4][5][6].

Employers must update their sick leave policies and workplace posters to reflect these expanded reasons and notify employees of their rights under the HFWA by the effective date. The law continues to require accrual of at least one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, with a minimum annual cap of 48 hours, which can be carried over to the next year. Employers may request reasonable documentation only if the leave exceeds four consecutive workdays. The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended on June 9, 2023 [1][2][4][6].

These changes reflect Colorado’s response to increasing extreme weather events and other unexpected circumstances affecting employees’ ability to work, ensuring broader protections for paid leave use beyond traditional health-related needs [2].
optimizations.modified_content:
Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

In addition, effective August 7, 2023, Colorado expanded the HFWA via Senate Bill 23-017 to broaden the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave. These new reasons include:  
- Bereavement leave to grieve or attend funeral services of a family member;  
- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.  

Employers are required to notify employees of these new rights and update their paid sick leave policies and workplace posters accordingly. Colorado is expected to publish updated official posters reflecting these amendments. Employers should ensure their sick leave policies and posters reflect these changes by the effective date.  

The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies to reflect this termination.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.  

*Note: The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies accordingly.*  

### Recordkeeping  
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.  

### Anti-Retaliation  
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.  

### Notice to Employees  
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.

Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. optimizations.query: what are the legal requirements for employer-provided sick leave?
optimizations.final_answer:
Employer-provided sick leave legal requirements vary by jurisdiction, but key elements include eligibility, accrual, usage, and notice obligations.

1. **Federal Level (U.S.)**:  
There is currently no federal mandate requiring paid sick leave for private-sector employees. However, the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) requires eligible employees to be granted up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for certain medical and family reasons. Eligibility under FMLA requires at least 12 months of employment, 1,250 hours worked in the past year, and working at a location with 50 or more employees within 75 miles. Paid leave may substitute for unpaid FMLA leave if employer policies allow [2].

2. **State and Local Laws (Example: California)**:  
Starting January 1, 2024, California employers must provide at least 5 days or 40 hours of paid sick leave annually to employees who work at least 30 days for the same employer within a year. This includes part-time, temporary, and staffing agency employees, with some narrow exemptions (e.g., certain airline crew, railroad workers, and employees covered by qualifying collective bargaining agreements). Employees accrue sick leave or may receive it upfront depending on the employer’s policy. Employers must post updated notices about sick leave rights. Local ordinances requiring more generous sick leave supersede state law except in specific areas where state law preempts local rules (e.g., paystub statements, timing of payment) [1].

3. **State Example: Colorado**:  
Under the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), Colorado employers must provide up to 48 hours (6 days) of paid sick leave per year, accruing at a rate of 1 hour per 30 hours worked, with immediate accrual and use upon hire. Employers may frontload leave instead of accrual. Sick leave can be used for personal or family illness, preventive care, domestic violence-related needs, public health emergencies, bereavement, and other expanded reasons effective August 2023. Employees must be allowed to take leave in one-hour increments (or smaller if employer permits). Employers cannot require employees to find replacements as a condition for leave. Unused leave carries over up to 48 hours but employers can limit annual use to 48 hours. There is no payout requirement for unused leave at separation, but reinstatement is required if rehired within six months [6].

4. **General Legal Requirements Across Jurisdictions**:  
- Employers must allow employees to accrue or receive paid sick leave upfront.  
- Employees generally qualify after a minimum period of employment (e.g., 30 days in California, immediate in Colorado).  
- Sick leave can be used for diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care for the employee or family members, and for certain qualifying events like domestic violence or public health emergencies.  
- Employers must provide clear notice of sick leave rights and post required informational posters.  
- Employers cannot retaliate against employees for using sick leave or require unreasonable conditions such as finding a replacement worker.  
- Accrued but unused sick leave often must carry over to the next year, though usage limits may apply.  
- Some states or localities require payout of unused sick leave upon separation, but others do not.  
- Collective bargaining agreements may modify or partially exempt employers from sick leave laws if they meet specific criteria [1][6].

5. **Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Considerations**:

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.

(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.

- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and

The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.

In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;

In addition to handbook templates and legal guidance, many employers benefit from using leave management software to streamline compliance with Colorado’s HFWA. Colorado’s paid sick leave policies are governed primarily by the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), which mandates that all employers provide paid sick leave to employees, with specific accrual, usage, and job protection rules.

**Coverage and Eligibility:**  
- The HFWA applies to all employers with one or more employees in Colorado, including part-time, seasonal, and temporary workers. Independent contractors are excluded.  
- Employees become eligible to accrue paid sick leave immediately upon hire and may begin using it as it accrues. However, job protection against retaliation for using sick leave applies only after 180 days of continuous employment. Before this period, employees can use leave but without guaranteed job protection [2][3][6].

**Accrual and Caps:**  
- Employees earn at least 1 hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked.  
- The maximum accrual and usage limit is 48 hours (6 days) per year, though employers may choose to provide more.  
- Employers may either track accrual or front-load the full 48 hours at the start of the year.  
- Unused leave carries over year to year without limit, but usage in any calendar year cannot exceed 48 hours unless the employer allows more [1][2][3][6].

**Permitted Uses of Paid Sick Leave:**  
- Leave can be used for the employee’s own physical or mental illness, injury, or preventive care.  
- It can also be used to care for a family member with similar health needs. Colorado’s definition of “family member” is broader than many states, including anyone for whom the employee provides or arranges health- or safety-related care.  
- Additional reasons include recovery from or services related to domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; bereavement leave; care for family members affected by school or care closures due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and evacuation due to utility loss or weather emergencies.  
- Preventive care and mental health treatment are explicitly covered.  
- Employers cannot require documentation for absences shorter than four consecutive workdays [2][3][4][6].

**Public Health Emergency Leave:**  
- Separate from accrued leave, employees are entitled to supplemental leave during public health emergencies (e.g., COVID-19 pandemic), with up to 80 hours provided for qualifying reasons such as self-isolation, symptoms, or exposure to communicable illnesses declared as emergencies. This supplemental leave ended in June 2023 but was integrated into the HFWA framework [1][6].

**Notice and Documentation:**  
- Employees must provide notice as soon as practicable for emergency leave and reasonable advance notice for foreseeable leave.  
- Employers may adopt reasonable written policies for notice but cannot deny leave for noncompliance.  
- Documentation can only be required for absences of four or more consecutive days [2][6].

**Job Protection and Anti-Retaliation:**  
- After 180 days of employment, employees are protected from retaliation or adverse employment actions for taking legitimate paid sick leave.  
- Retaliation includes termination, demotion, reduced hours, or exclusion from meetings [2][6].

**Coordination with Other Leave Laws:**  
- Colorado’s paid sick leave law operates alongside other leave laws such as the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and the state’s Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) program, which provides partial wage replacement for up to 16 weeks.  
- Employers cannot require employees to use accrued PTO or vacation before or during FAMLI leave but may allow voluntary supplementation.  
- “Use-it-or-lose-it” vacation or PTO policies are prohibited; accrued paid leave must carry over and be paid out upon separation [4].

**Recordkeeping and Compliance:**  
- Employers must maintain records of hours worked, sick leave accrued, and leave used for at least three to four years.  
- They must post official HFWA notices and provide written notice of rights at hire and annually.  
- Noncompliance can result in escalating penalties starting at $50 per violation, with higher fines for willful or repeated violations [1][2][4].

**Summary:**  
Colorado’s paid sick leave policies under the HFWA are comprehensive, requiring all employers to provide paid sick leave accrued at 1 hour per 30 worked, with a 48-hour annual cap on usage, broad permissible uses including mental health and domestic violence-related leave, strong job protections after 180 days, and strict recordkeeping and notice requirements. The law’s broad coverage and unique provisions, such as expanded family definitions and integration with the FAMLI program, make compliance complex, especially for employers operating in multiple states [1][2][3][4][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

In addition, effective August 7, 2023, Colorado expanded the HFWA via Senate Bill 23-017 to broaden the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave. These new reasons include:  
- Bereavement leave to grieve or attend funeral services of a family member;  
- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.  

Employers are required to notify employees of these new rights and update their paid sick leave policies and workplace posters accordingly. Colorado is expected to publish updated official posters reflecting these amendments. Employers should ensure their sick leave policies and posters reflect these changes by the effective date.  

The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies to reflect this termination.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or

Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.

optimizations.final_answer:
SHRM outlines that employer obligations for sick leave vary significantly by jurisdiction, with many states and cities enacting their own paid sick leave laws that employers must comply with. Key employer responsibilities include determining coverage applicability, employee eligibility, accrual and usage rules, and compliance with overlapping laws, often applying the most generous provisions to employees.

1. **Coverage and Eligibility**: Employers must first determine if their business is covered under applicable paid sick leave laws, which often exclude very small businesses or certain industries. Employees typically begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire, but usage may be restricted until after a waiting period (e.g., 90 days in California). Eligibility can depend on where the employee performs work, complicating compliance for mobile workers [1].

2. **Accrual and Usage**: Paid sick leave accrual rates and caps differ by jurisdiction. For example, California employees accrue one hour of paid sick leave per 30 hours worked, with a cap on usage of 24 hours per year, while Washington employees accrue one hour per 40 hours worked with a 40-hour carryover limit. Employers may frontload sick leave instead of accrual. Leave can generally be used for the employee’s own illness or to care for family members, though definitions of "family" vary widely [1].

3. **Family and Safe Time Definitions**: Laws vary on who qualifies as a family member for leave purposes, often including children, spouses, parents, and sometimes domestic partners or close associates. Many laws also provide "safe time" for victims of domestic violence, sexual assault, or stalking, allowing leave for medical care, counseling, legal services, or relocation [1].

4. **Multiple Laws and Industry-Specific Rules**: Employers must navigate overlapping laws at state, local, and industry levels, applying the most generous rules to employees. For example, a hotel employee in Los Angeles may be covered by state, city, and hotel-specific sick leave laws [1].

5. **Employee Obligations**: Employees generally must provide notice of leave, which can be oral or written, and employers may establish reasonable notice procedures. Employers cannot require employees to find replacement workers as a condition for leave [3].

6. **Example: Colorado’s Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA)**: Colorado requires employers to provide up to 48 hours of paid sick leave annually, accruing at one hour per 30 hours worked, with immediate use upon accrual. Leave can be used for personal or family illness, preventive care, domestic abuse-related needs, public health emergencies, bereavement, and other expanded reasons. Employers must notify employees of rights and update policies accordingly. Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless otherwise permitted. Employers are not required to pay out unused leave at separation but must reinstate unused leave if rehiring within six months [6].

In summary, SHRM emphasizes that employer obligations for sick leave require careful attention to the specific laws applicable to their workforce, including accrual, usage, family definitions, and safe time provisions. Employers should maintain updated policies, provide employee notifications, and apply the most generous leave provisions when multiple laws overlap to ensure compliance and support employee well-being [1][3][6].

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.  
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.  
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.  
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.  

### Employee Eligibility  
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.  

### How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave  
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.  
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.  
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.  

### Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:  
The employee:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee needs to care for a family member who:  
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;  
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or  
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.  
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:  
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;  
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;  
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or  
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;  
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:  
(i) The employee’s place of business; or  
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.  

In addition, effective August 7, 2023, Colorado expanded the HFWA via Senate Bill 23-017 to broaden the reasons employees may use accrued paid sick leave. These new reasons include:  
- Bereavement leave to grieve or attend funeral services of a family member;  
- Leave to care for a family member whose school or place of care is closed due to inclement weather or other unexpected events; and  
- Leave to evacuate the employee’s residence due to inclement weather or utility loss.  

Employers are required to notify employees of these new rights and update their paid sick leave policies and workplace posters accordingly. Colorado is expected to publish updated official posters reflecting these amendments. Employers should ensure their sick leave policies and posters reflect these changes by the effective date.  

The supplemental public health emergency leave related to COVID-19 ended in June 2023, and employers should update their policies to reflect this termination.  

### Taking Paid Sick Leave  
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.  
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.  
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.  

### Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.  

### Paid Sick Leave at Separation  
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.  
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.  
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.  

### Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)  
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”  
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.  
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):  
An employee’s need to:  
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(v) Care for a family member who:  
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or  
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;  
Or if:  
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
Or to:  
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;  
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;  
Or due to:  
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.  
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.

Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.

The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.  
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.  
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.  
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.

Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division.
